title: 104_hr851
content:
The "Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995" is established to promote telemedicine services in rural areas. The "Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995" establishes up to 10 pilot projects to study the use of rural health care provider telemedicine networks for physician consultative services under Medicare in rural areas. A rural health care provider telemedicine network is defined as a network of providers serving physicians, clinics, and nontertiary care providers in rural areas. The Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995 establishes pilot projects for rural health care provider telemedicine networks in designated rural areas, focusing on patient referral, joint communications systems, and transportation among network members. The network operates in rural health professional shortage areas or underserved rural areas as specified by the Secretary. The Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995 establishes pilot projects for rural health care provider telemedicine networks in designated rural areas, focusing on patient referral, joint communications systems, and transportation among network members. Medicare payment for participants is addressed in Section 3 of the Act. The Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995 establishes pilot projects for rural health care provider telemedicine networks in designated rural areas. The Secretary will make payments from the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund for physicians' services in rural areas, regardless of location. A methodology will be established for determining payment amounts based on available funds. The Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995 establishes pilot projects for rural health care provider telemedicine networks in designated rural areas. Payments may be made for physician consultative services, including reasonable costs for signal transmission facilities. Nonphysician providers can also receive payments for services described in the act. The Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995 establishes pilot projects for rural health care provider telemedicine networks. Networks must meet eligibility criteria and agree to provide necessary information to participate. The act also defines "rural area" and outlines criteria for selecting participants. SEC. 5. CRITERIA FOR SELECTING PARTICIPANTS.

Priority given to networks enabling consultations between patients and specialists through detailed data transmission. Existing networks can participate in pilot projects.

SEC. 6. REPORTS. The Secretary must submit an interim report to Congress within 24 months of making payments for pilot project services, detailing participating projects and networks, expenses, and patient numbers. A final report is due within 1 year after project termination, analyzing cost-effectiveness, success in rural provider access to specialist consultations, and impact on patient care quality. The Secretary must provide recommendations for changes in the medicare program related to telemedicine, including cost estimates. Authorization of appropriations from the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund for a total of $51,000,000 for a demonstration project under this Act, with up to $1,000,000 allocated for administrative purposes.
